awd_titl_txt: Focusing Cosmic Telescopes on the Distant Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
Galaxy clusters act as "cosmic telescopes" that magnify distant galaxies, making them appear bigger and brighter and therefore easier to detect. If we want to better understand the intrinsic properties of the distant galaxies, it is important to make a "lens model" of the mass distribution of the cluster to make a model of the magnifications of the distant galaxies. All current models seem to missing something since they disagree with each other. This project will look at the assumptions and missing effects from the current models to try to build a better understanding of the uncertainties in lens models.

The proposed project will improve the state of gravitational lens modeling by developing a framework for reconciling discrepancies between different models for reconstructing lensing maps. The project will incorporate four new effects: scatter in cluster member galaxy properties, lensing by line-of-sight galaxies outside the cluster, structure along the line of sight, and non-galaxy structure within the cluster. They will use this framework to see whether the new effects can reconcile current lens models, and present the framework as an open-source code module so that it can be used in future cluster lens modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Gravitational lensing by galaxy clusters can make distant background galaxies appear bigger and brighter and therefore easier to detect. In order to determine the intrinsic properties of these galaxies, we must "de-lens" them using gravitational lens models. This project aimed to improve the state of cluster lens modeling by understanding systematic uncertainties that can lead to discrepancies between models from different teams. It also introduced first-year undergraduate students to modeling in a variety of realms, teaching students to recognize simplifying assumptions and think critically about how those do or do not limit a model's applicability.

Intellectual merit. This project introduced a new framework for cluster lens modeling that explicitly incorporates multiple effects (dark matter and galaxies within the cluster, galaxies along the line of sight, and other large-scale structure). Raney et al. (2020) presented a detailed comparison of lens models from different teams for the six Hubble Frontier Fields. We found that circularly-averaged mass profiles are remarkably robust but magnifications often vary by more than the statistical uncertainties. Raney et al. (2021) then used our new modeling framework to begin a comprehensive analysis of design choices that may cause models to differ. We found that model results are robust to reasonable choices for the magnitude and radial cuts used to select cluster members for inclusion in lens models. Lensing magnifications are modestly sensitive to the luminosity/mass scaling relations used to assign mass to cluster member galaxies. Zimmerman et al. (2021) studied how models are affected by the choice of lensed images used as constraints. It is more important to have images be spatially distributed around the cluster than to have them distributed in redshift. The most significant model constraints typically come from image sets with an image that lies close to a lensing critical curve as well as an image that is relatively isolated from other images. Additional undergraduate students have examined methods used to select galaxies that belong to a cluster, and lensing effects of large-scale structure along the line of sight to the source. With our improved understanding of cluster lens modeling, we were able to contribute to the analysis of the merging cluster ACT-CL J0034.4+0225 discovered by Doze et al. (2023). Even when we accounted for significant uncertainties in lens models, the lensing analysis strongly supports the inference from X-ray and optical data that the system is in a merger state with the western component being the more massive one.

Broader impacts. The project supported the research training of three graduate students and four undergraduate students, who led or contributed to the research work discussed above. It also introduced first-year undergraduate students to modeling in a variety of realms through a course for the Byrne Seminars Program at Rutgers. Through a series of case studies, we examined how models are built and used, with special focus on identifying simplifications and assumptions in order to understand circumstances in which the models should be reliable. Topics included astrophysics, biology, geology, meteorology, economics, recommender systems, COVID-19 models, polling, and transportation. We examined these topics through visits from experts so Rutgers first-year students could meet and interact with scholars from many fields. The pedagogical approach included learning how to approach unfamiliar topics and formulate good questions to help prepare students for interacting with and learning from the expert visitors.
